claim: All cats are mammals. Tigers belong to the cat family. Therefore, tigers are mammals

supporting.text: All members of the cat family (Felidae) are classified as mammals by biological taxonomy.

attacks.text: All members of the cat family (Felidae) are classified as mammals by biological taxonomy.
Some members of the cat family may exhibit traits that blur the line between mammals and other classes, such as monotremes.
Monotremes are not part of the Felidae family; they belong to a separate order (Monotremata) and are not relevant to the classification of cats.
Taxonomic classifications can change with new scientific discoveries, potentially reclassifying some Felidae members.
Current consensus in biological taxonomy strongly supports the classification of all Felidae as mammals, with no evidence suggesting reclassification.

supporting.text: Tigers (Panthera tigris) share the defining mammalian characteristics such as mammary glands and hair.

attacks.text: Tigers (Panthera tigris) share the defining mammalian characteristics such as mammary glands and hair.
Some rare genetic mutations in tigers could theoretically result in non-mammalian traits, challenging the universality of the claim.
Genetic mutations causing non-mammalian traits in tigers are speculative and have never been observed in nature or documented scientifically.
The definition of 'mammal' is culturally relative; some indigenous classifications might not align with the biological taxonomy.
Scientific taxonomy is based on empirical evidence and universal criteria, not cultural perspectives, ensuring consistent classification of tigers as mammals.

supporting.text: The biological order Carnivora, which includes all cat species, is universally recognized as mammalian.

attacks.text: The biological order Carnivora, which includes all cat species, is universally recognized as mammalian.
Some members of Carnivora, like the extinct Thylacoleo, were marsupials and not true mammals.
Thylacoleo is not classified within Felidae (the cat family), so it doesn't affect the mammalian status of cats.
The definition of 'mammal' is sometimes disputed for monotremes like platypuses, calling into question the clarity of the classification.
Monotremes are universally accepted as mammals in modern taxonomy, despite their egg-laying reproduction.

supporting.text: All extant species within the Felidae family exhibit mammalian traits like live birth and three middle ear bones.

attacks.text: All extant species within the Felidae family exhibit mammalian traits like live birth and three middle ear bones.
Some extinct Felidae species may not have exhibited all mammalian traits, casting doubt on the universality of the claim.
Fossil evidence overwhelmingly supports that even extinct Felidae species shared core mammalian traits with their extant relatives.
Genetic mutations could theoretically produce a Felidae species that lacks one or more mammalian traits.
No documented cases exist of Felidae species lacking core mammalian traits, making this a purely hypothetical scenario.
